Lore: "Ben. . . Ben, please! Ben. . . Leia! Hear me, Leia!"
Gametext: Deploy on table. You may not play Imperial Barrier. Senators are deploy +2. Whenever you initiate a battle, may retrieve your topmost non-[Permanent Weapon], non-[Maintenance] character. May place the top card of your Reserve Deck in Lost Pile to place a combat card in owner's Lost Pile. (Immune to Alter.)
Information: Startable with Prepared Defenses.\par -----\par Article at DeckTech, September 19th, 2005\par Top 5 Battle-Aiding V-Cards (Dark Side) by Armaedes and Shewski\par \par In my opinion, this is the greatest battling promoter in the history of the game. This card will work in just about any battling deck. While Scum And Villainy requires aliens on the table and Imperial Domination (V) requires that you play with only Imperials, Ability, Ability, Ability (V) can work in any deck that has non-permanent weapon, non-maintenance characters. In fact, it will work even if you are playing some EPPs or maintenance characters!\par \par The retrieval aspect of this card is merely the most obvious reason why this is a solid battling promoter. The second line of the gametext prohibits the playing of Imperial Barrier, the oldest and most widely used dark side battle hinderer. This promotes battling if for no other reason than that it prevents the dark side player from using the easiest form of battle evasion. In other words, even though this is a dark side card it can also help light side battling decks!\par \par This card further promotes battling by hindering two of the most potentially non-interactive decktypes around, senate and lightsaber combat. This card slows down light senate, which has long revolved around a combination of big drains and frustrating hit-and-run tactics with EPPs. It also hurts lightsaber combat, which is the objective that is perhaps most designed to avoid battling.\par \par All in all, this card manages to accomplish the greatest stride towards creating a battle-oriented environment, making it number one on my list.\par \par SHEWSKI'S TAKE:\par Amen, man. I rank this as my #1 DS aid as well. As I mentioned in the LS article, I think that the anti-Senate/LSC was a bit much to fit into this card and hurt those decks a bit too much. A very strong card, a bit stronger than Civil Disorder, I think. See my review below for why!\par A must play in many decks, AAA revolutionized the SWCCG world when it was released and still continues to be a popular play. Part of its strength was that it could play as well with its "taboo" characters (EPPs and maintenance guys) as without them. As long as you had a few key guys to keep looping onto the table, you could take full advantage of its text. While I don't like the anti-Senate and Combat text, it made it easier to rationalize including this in your decks. I believe that AAA is stronger than CD since its senator text will hit more often for the DS (targeting Leia and Mon Mothma) that the LS. In fact, when characters are designed to work around this Effect, you know it's a prominent one.\par \par ARMAEDES' TAKE:\par The only advantage I can see Civil Disorder (V) having over this card is that Civil Disorder (V) makes a mean combination with Quick Draw (V). This is #1 on my list as well and is maybe one of the best cards ever made by the Player's Committee. Although I find the anti-senator text to be fine, I do agree with you that the anti-combat text might have been a bit of an overkill move as it almost completely invalidates the decktype. However, when you're looking at battling aids it's hard to beat a card that lets you get back your characters so that you can keep on battling.
IsPulled: Twi'lek Advisor\par We Must Accelerate Our Plans

Lore: "Give the evacuation code signal ... and get to your transports!"
Gametext: Deploy on table; shuffle your Reserve Deck, peek at top three cards, and stack them face-up here. During battle, may take a card here into hand to prevent all battle destiny draws from being modified or canceled (each player may draw no more than one battle destiny). (Immune to Alter.)
Information: Startable with Heading For The Medical Frigate.\par -----\par Article at DeckTech, September 19th, 2005\par Top 5 Battle-Aiding V-Cards (Light Side) by Armaedes and Shewski\par \par The reason this card is on the list is because it makes light side immunity mains good again. Now instead of dropping your EPP and taking out a couple of characters, you can drop down your immunity main and take out a couple of characters and still have the immunity main around next turn to drain on the location. This also stops your opponent from messing with your destiny draw via the senate objective, which is important if you want to really cause some battle damage. Although this card appears more defensive in nature it can actually be a very powerful offensive card.\par \par SHEWSKI'S TAKE:\par This ranks just outside my top 5 on both sides. CD/AAA have already conditioned you to getting more mileage out your immunity mains, this just reinforces that principle. I don't like this in the early game in case a key card gets trapped under the Effect, but mid-game onwards it is a welcome play. I think this will also give those decks that rely solely upon immunity mains (THGG, WHAP, Invasion) a little bump into playability. Remember, total battle destiny can still be affected!!\par -----\par This is the card old-school Star Wars CCG players have been waiting for since Reflections 3, a card that finally makes it to where your opponent can't use Boba Fett, Bounty Hunter, IG-88 With Riot Gun and 4-LOM With Concussion Rifle aboard Zuckuss In Mist Hunter to instantly end the game in a battle destiny-adding frenzy. Play this card - which you can start - and three battles per game you can limit both players to one battle destiny. Play two of this non-unique card and it's good for six battles per game, and few games have more than six battles (and not many have more than three).\par \par So besides limiting destiny-adding fetishes, what does this card really mean for light side? For one thing, it means light side immunity mains are back. Ben Kenobi being immune < 5 used to mean nothing when he was facing multiple draws. Now immune < 5 can only be cracked by a solid destiny draw. Luke Skywalker, Jedi Knight armed with his saber is basically immune to attrition. Obi-Wan Kenobi (V) is even better.\par \par This card also works well in space. Playing I'll Take The Leader to give your Outrider immunity < 6 is huge now. The Millenium Falcon with the same Admiral's Order out is only going down to a draw of 7 or better. Red 5 (V) is immune to attrition < 6 at base. Home One is basically invincible.\par \par This card really brings SWCCG back to where it should be - when main characters are able to stay on the table for more than a turn or two, and your opponent really has to bring the beats to get rid of a big, bad main. Matching pilot starships are also a lot stronger now, and all of this is tempered by the fact that you can't play Bright Hope (V) and Tantive IV (V) and rule the sky by cancelling your opponent's only destiny draw. This is also a great card to use if you find yourself going against a destiny-cancelling team, as using this effect will prevent your destiny draw from being cancelled.\par \par This card is going to make a lot of light side decks viable again, as they won't have to worry about the Super-Fett beatdown as much. Dont' get goldenrody though - your opponent will still be able to brign a lot of power in your direction. Below is a deck that takes advantage of the newfound respect light mains are going to get due to this card.
IsPulled: It's Not My Fault (V)\par The Signal\par We Wish To Board At Once

Lore: Occasionally Han was capable of such feats, even without Threepio there to tell him these things.
Gametext: Deploy on table. Play with the top card of your Reserve Deck revealed (if possible). During your draw phase, place this Effect in Used Pile and you may retrieve 1 Force.
Information: Articel on DeckTech, October 31st, 2005\par Top 5 Damage-Controlling V-Cards (Light Side) by Armaedes and Shewski\par \par Possibly the most effective retrieval card around, Flash Of Insight (V) is a free retrieval of one card per turn that is unaffected by Come Here You Big Coward, Do They Have A Code Clearance?, Secret Plans, or Allegations Of Corruption. As if that wasn't enough, it also lets you check out your top destiny, which is always a good thing (even if your opponent gets to see it too). At destiny-4, there's no reason why every light deck shouldn't have at least one Flash (V) in it, and more likely you should have 3-4. With Threepio With His Parts Showing or Mirax Terrik on the table you can play one every single turn with a bare minimum of tracking, and getting a risk-free card from your lost pile back into your deck while also cycling a decently-high-destiny Effect back into your deck is always a good thing.\par \par SHEWSKI'S TAKE:\par I make this my top damage controller; mainly since it can fit in any deck out there, the sheer versatility of this card is amazing. There truly are lots of little tricks you can do with this card that I hope to share in my review of it:\par Flash is one of those cards that you can fit into ANY deck, and it's so strong that you may often be tempted to slip in multiples. Generally, with proper tracking you can get a lot of use of just one copy. This card is a great way to learn how to track- you can track the Effect itself, the card "retrieved", or use it to check another destiny you were already tracking. Note the parentheses on retrieved, this is not retrieval, so it is not affected by cards that hamper general retrieval. I think my favorite use of this card is to check destinies early in the game, when you are shuffling so much that tracking is a few turns away at best. I play Flash, and then generally use every shuffling technique available to me until I get the destiny I want to see. In the heyday of Walkers, it was quite easy to get a high destiny so I could launch a Corran beatdown. My second favorite use of the card was in conjunction with cards like Naked Threepio, by using various shuffling techniques I could also get the choice of a few different cards I could draw into hand. The destiny isn't too bad, either! Beware, Flash is nice Alter bait- while there are plenty of worse cards your opponent can let through your nice "retrieval" cycle might end prematurely.\par \par ARMAEDES' TAKE:\par I couldn't agree more; Flash (V) can literally go in any light side deck, and it requires no effort whatsoever to pull it off - you don't even have to have Force available, since it's not "retrieval" and therefore immune to Secret Plans. This is by far the most universal retrieval method available for light side.
IsPulled: It's Not My Fault (V)\par The Signal\par We Wish To Board At Once
Combo: Flash Of Insight (V5) + On The Edge\par Easy retrieval.

Information: Article at DeckTech, November 1st, 2005\par Top 5 Damage-Controlling V-Cards (Dark Side) by Armaedes and Shewski\par \par It's a destiny-6 card that can be pulled from your deck using Masterful Move, and can reduce Force drain damage with the only stipulation being that it must be a planet site (so no Cloud City locations). There's really no easier way to reduce damage, as it requires no commitment from the Dark Side player other than that they commit a card slot to a destiny-6 Effect. If Vader's hanging around an adjacent site, this card will obviously become even more powerful. Simple Effect that can make a huge difference in a game.\par \par SHEWSKI'S TAKE:\par \par Wow, talk about an obvious miss on my part- great idea for a damage controller. The LS version (Projection of a Skywalker) was played quite a bit for similar reasons. The one thing that I don't like about this card is its fixed location. If you temper a drain at a planet where there are multiple sites, your opponent can always move around it. It works best at key drain locations where the enhancers (unlike lightsabers) are fixed as well.

Lore: To Imperial command personnel: The Rebellion must be crushed! Minor acts of sedition are to be ignored. The destruction of the Alliance is your primary goal.
Gametext: Deploy on table. At start of your turn, may lose 1 Force to activate this turn using (Light Side Force icon) instead of (Dark Side Force icon). Whenever you lose Force (except from Force drains, battle damage, or your card), may reduce loss (to a minimum of 1) by the number of battlegrounds you occupy. (Immune to Alter.)
Information: Startable with Prepared Defenses.\par -----\par Good against direct damage like Uncontrollable Fury, Legendary Starfighter, Anger, Fear, Aggression or the WHAP Objective flipside.\par -----\par Article at DeckTech, November 1st, 2005\par Top 5 Damage-Controlling V-Cards (Dark Side) by Armaedes and Shewski\par \par When this card was first released, I have to admit that I was pretty disappointed. After all, it hurt one of my favorite strategies (Force denial). However, after some serious play with this card, I have changed my mind completely and now consider this to be one of the better cards released by the Player's Committee. There are lots of forms of direct damage for Light Side, and this card can reduce most of them. Imperial Decree (V) also has a solid balancing factor: Dark Side must control battlegrounds to make the damage-reduction work. This discourages Dark Side "turtle decks" while also giving Light Side the option to still have their direct damage - as long as they're willing to fight for it. Solid damage controller that also promotes interaction - an excellent quality in a card, in my opinion.\par \par SHEWSKI'S TAKE:\par \par A consensus pick! Who would have thunk it?? I like how this seems to cycle in and out of decks, which means that denial is still a valid option in small doses. Don't despair, Armaedes!\par For years, Dark Side players wanted to know if they would ever get a card comparable to Honor of the Jedi. Fortunately, the answer was yes. This card is a nice staple in many DS decks. First, I enjoy the fact that its' a cousin of Honor, not an outright twin. Its text promotes interaction via battleground deployment and it lets some damage through no matter what. I haven't used the activation text very much, but the very threat of it generally neutered Revolution heavy choke decks like some versions of TRM. I rank this card so high since it so easy to slip in virtually any deck, but its usefulness has slipped with the lack of direct damage heavy LS decks in the meta. Most LS damage seems to come from battle damage anymore, but in the days of Speeders and WHAP this card was a difference maker.\par \par ARMAEDES' TAKE:\par Couldn't agree more; this is a very powerful card for the Dark Side and belongs in just about every Dark deck under the sun. I had forgotten to mention that this card still hurts Revolution like the original Decree did.
IsPulled: Field Promotion (V5)\par Twi'lek Advisor\par We Must Accelerate Our Plans

Lore: When Vader's forces impose the New Order upon a region, Rebel resources and lifelines are quickly eliminated.
Gametext: Deploy on table. If your non-Imperial character or [Independent] starship on table, this Effect lost. Unless you occupy fewer locations than opponent: if you initiate or win a battle, retrieve an Imperial; and, during battle, may take an Imperial just drawn for destiny into hand to cancel and redraw that destiny. (Immune to Alter.)
Information: Startable with Prepared Defenses.\par -----\par Article at DeckTech, September 19th, 2005\par Top 5 Battle-Aiding V-Cards (Dark Side) by Armaedes and Shewski\par \par Like Ability, Ability, Ability (V), but harder to use due to the fact that you can only play with Imperials if you use this card. In addition to offering some solid character retrieval, this card also does a decent job of causing your opponent to spread out quickly so that they can suspend the gametext of this card. The battle destiny limiting may seem like a bad idea for a battling deck, but in reality there aren't a lot of ways for all-Imperial decks to get multiple battle destiny anyway, and this way you can use characters like Lord Vader and have the immunity to attrition be worth more than if you had to worry about your opponent drawing 5 battle destiny and basically making your immunity worthless. Another reason this is a solid battling card is because if you draw battle or weapon destiny and accidentally flip a character, you can take it into hand and try again, allowing you to play with more characters than you would normally be able to get away with while still maintaining the integrity of the deck's destiny.\par \par SHEWSKI'S TAKE:\par Wow, great minds think alike. This is my #5 as well. I really like the versatility that this card brings to an Imperial deck and think that as stronger Imperials are created this card will see more and more play.\par Armaedes made a bunch of good points about this card above, but there were a few things I also wanted to add. First, two copies of this can be played for maximum use, which means twice as many benefits heading your way. It may be overkill in many instances, but if it is worth it, you'll never go without characters ever again. Secondly, there are some creative ways for you to use it as a cycling machine. DDM had an interesting Hunt Down that used a lone Womp Rat to constantly draw against Vader so that he could draw needed Imperials into hand. I also don't think that limited destiny draws as a bad thing- with you constantly weeding out low destiny characters your 2 destinies should be stronger than your opponent's. This is also yet another great battle winning effect that works with many of the other cards on this list.\par \par ARMAEDES' TAKE:\par No argument here, and the two-copies thing is an important point I forgot to mention. I have seen this card used effectively in Hunt Down, BHBM, ISB, Ralltiir, and even some Combat Readiness (V) decks. Like Ability, Ability, Ability (V), it's good because it rewards you for battling by giving you more characters to battle with. Unlike Ability, Ability, Ability (V), it's far more deck-specific, but getting back characters is always a good thing.
IsPulled: Field Promotion (V5)\par Twi'lek Advisor\par We Must Accelerate Our Plans

Rebels are deploy +1 to Hoth sites. Your total battle destiny at Hoth system is +1 for each Imperial there. Unless opponent controls a Hoth location, your Force drain bonuses may not be canceled. Once per turn, when you deploy an AT-AT, may retrieve any one card (except an Interrupt or vehicle) into hand. During your deploy phase, may deploy a marker site from Reserve Deck; reshuffle. \par \b Flip\b0  this card if Hoth Blockade not on Hoth.
Information: Article on DeckTech, August 19th, 2007 '2nd Annual SWCCG Encyclopedia of Decks' by Brandon "Jabba_the_Ruck" Ruck\par http://www.decktech.net/starwarsccg/articles/articles.php?id=6526&view=2\par \par Popular Cards to Look For: Blizzard 4, Blizzard 2 (V4), Tempest 1, Blizzard 1 (V4 or non-V), version of Veers, version of Vader, Target the Main Generator, Walker Garrison, 3rd Marker, Sando Aqua Monster, Tatooine Maul, Maul's Sith Infiltrator, Imperial Decree (V6 & non-V), and You May Start Your Landing\par \par Idea Behind Objective: The first DS objective created by the PC. It was the exact opposite to Speeders and another great movie objective. For a long time, Walkers was the strongest DS deck to be played. Only with the creation of stronger LS decks did this deck become less powerful. Even though the deck could be beat, it was considered way too strong. It was able to blow the shields by turn 3 since the objective could pull Blizzard 4 to set up Vader. The PC ended up having to completely change this deck the same way they changed Speeders and WYS (V8). The basic idea is still the same. Get out a non-maintenance Walker, equip it with AT-AT Cannon (V4), get a high enough ability pilot on the Walker, and blow the shields. The minute they go, the LS loses 8 Force from the Shields, then another 1 direct damage from You May Start Your Landing since the Walker only has to occupy the site. From there, you set up at least one Walker at the different non-battleground Marker sites, usually 4th, 5th, and 6th. YMSYL lets you pull the 3rd Marker and Walker Garrison, if you started the game with that card on table. You can pull those two cards and deploy the 3rd Marker after you blow the shields. It is VERY important to never deploy the 3rd Marker until after the shields are gone. Your forces at the 3rd Marker can get stuck which means, unless you are playing the Electro-Rangefinder, you will have to deploy to the Plains and move over. The LS can throw as much as they want at you on their next turn because you gave them a site to battle you at. The Hoth shield prevents you from deploying directly to the 3rd marker until the shield is blown away, which means that you will not be able to fortify the Walker that was moved over the previous turn. Once the shield has been blown away, you can spread out and have a solid force set up on the 3rd Maker. You can play Walker Garrison once per game (now that it's an Out of Play Interrupt) to drain for 10 to 15. The good thing is they made it immune to Sense. So the only way to cancel it is with T-47 Battle Formation. The best strategy is always to blow the shields first before you think of doing anything else with this deck. If you fear a spy coming down first turn, some versions play with Corporal Dedrum (V5) who prevents opponent's spies and Jar Jar from deploying to same site. He can be found by Blizzard 4 or Commander Praji (V2) since he is both a pilot and a warrior. Walkers can be very easy to play since you win the majority of your games doing the exact same thing. Most of the time when the LS leaves you alone, you will auto win the game.\par \par How It Can Win: This objective wins because it can set up very fast damage that is almost impossible to cancel. The deck sets up on Hoth, so the DS has Imperial Decree at the start of the game to cancel all the LS drain bonuses. When you combine that with Imperial Decree (V6), Walkers can absorb both drains and direct damage very well. The deck also causes damage from non-battleground sites with You May Start Your Landing. The LS doesn't have as many ways to get around direct damage other than Honor Of The Jedi, so they usually have a tough time taking damage all game from YMSYL. The loss of 8 Force can also cause some key cards to be lost since most of the time the cards lost will come blindly from the Reserve deck. The deck doesn't rely on the use of Walker Garrison to win. Most of the time, by the time you are ready to play it, the opponent would already be well on their way to losing the game. The Garrison just finishes them off. The most powerful part of the objective is the ability to take ANY card you want from your lost pile back into hand once per turn when you deploy an AT-AT, and the AT-AT doesn't have to deploy to Hoth for this benefit to work. This used to be what made the deck so powerful, the Re Edit changed it so you can't take certain cards into hand. This is not near as powerful as before but it does allow you to keep your space and key power characters in play. Plus you can still take into hand Effects like Lateral Damage to abuse again and again.\par \par What Changed Since 1st Edition: The Re Edit changed how this deck could be built and played. Much like the LS objectives that were changed, this one became a very different deck from the original design. Now you can only find the Hoth icon AT-ATs. You can't pull Blizzard 4, Tempest 1, or the non-unique AT-ATs from the two player expansion. For some reason this was considered broken or too fast of a setup, so it was changed. Since you can't find Vader automatically anymore, this deck can take longer to blow the shields. When it was first changed, the answer to the problem came by starting Sando Aqua Monster and playing 6x Combat Readiness (V8). If you got a CR (V8) in your opening hand, you played it as your first action. Then it was placed on Sando so you had an auto 5 as your Epic Event draw. However, the Errata to Combat Readiness (V8) removed the ability to stack this card on your reserve. Since you knew your draw would be a 5, you could realistically blow the shields with any ability 3 pilot. Since Endor Shield (V11) pulls any Admiral, Moff, General, or Commander, you can pull the character that you need. If you start Inconsequential Losses (V9), you pull the Cannon when you deploy the AT-AT. So first turn, you pull the AT-AT if you didn't already have one. Blizzard 1 (V4) plays for just 4 Force. Veers (V10) deploys for 1 Force, so they can both go down for just 5. If you also pull Ozzel, you have a destiny just in case. If the LS doesn't get someone to the Ice Plains to keep you from controlling it, you auto blow the shields with the 5 on Sando, 3 from Veers, and 1 from the site. Your deck gives you 5 Force to start, so can always set this up against any LS match-up. Although you will have more problems against LS decks that go first since they have the ability to deploy to Hoth before your first turn. If they provide you just 1 more Force, you can use Blizzard 1 (non-V) to add another +1, so it doesn't matter if they deploy to the 1st Marker and move over. Besides this faster version, another option for setting up fast is to play a Free Executor version. You set up the Free Executor by starting Mob Points Combo and Kuat Drive Yards (V6). You have to play 3x WMAOPs, 2x TMNALTC, and 2x We're The Bait (V6). This gives you more than 73% chance you will get one in your opening hand. Once the Executor goes down, you can use Endor Shield (V11) to pull Admiral Piett, who then pulls Battle Deployment, which then pulls ANY vehicle. You don't have to do all of this on the same turn since it would give up a lot of searches for Thrown Back (V8). This version simply provides the ability to pull Blizzard 4 to set up Vader or Mara (V12) as well as continually pull vehicles after flipping. Plus the Executor is the hardest ship to knock out of space, so you set up a very solid presence in space that should survive all game to drain for free. You also increase the average destiny in the deck by replacing the lower destiny cards from it's space package with 5 destiny WMAOPs, 5 destiny TMNALTC, and 7 destiny We're The Bait (v).\par \par Why I SHOULD Play It: Walkers will always be a strong strategy because you are playing a deck that is based around powerful ground vehicles. The Re Edit did change how you set up and do damage and how long it takes you to blow up the generators. You no longer get 2x Walker Garrisons a game. This was sometimes what it took to win games against specific LS decks and now it is gone. Walkers can still be a powerful deck. You can slow down the LS damage very well with the Imperial Decrees and you have many options for red cards on Hoth. Ice Storm is always a popular card for making characters not in vehicles missing. You can play Sunsdown on Hoth with Frostbite (non-V) to cause 2 direct damage loss for each missing character. A very under played card that can really surprise some players is He Hasn't Come Back Yet. This Interrupt targets any LS character alone at ANY Marker site, is destiny +3> ability, targets are made missing. Endor Shield (V11) changed how the deck starts because you no longer have to play Imperial Commands to find General Veers (V4). Some versions choose to play with Krayt Dragon Bones (V4) which pulls both One Arm (V4) and Wampa (V4) from under your starting effect Fear is My Alley but that strategy may see less play with the Advanced Rules change to creature rules. There are also many chooses for the space package. Some play with bounty hunter ships and Tat Maul in space, yet others chose to play with Star Destroyers to benefit from the Prepared Defenses Text. Endor Shield (V11) has become a standard start for Walkers, so you can easily set up both General Veers (V4) on the ground and Thrawn in space. While you get a bonus from playing Imperials at the system, the best choice is the bounty hunters because they are much cheaper and can be redeployed from Lost pile after deploying AT-ATs. The new speed version of Walkers is probably the best strategy since you can cause key LS cards to be lost after their first turn of play. The speed version doesn't start You May Start Your Landing, so it is very important to always play 2x of them, plus 2 to 3 copies of We Must Accelerate Our Plans.\par \par Why NOT to Play It: Walkers is one of those DS decks that do the exact same thing every game. All decks that do the same thing can be a blessing as well as a curse since your opponent will always know exactly what you will be doing each turn. Because Walkers was so strong for so long, many LS players have experience playing against it. There are many things that can hurt this deck. The main one is not being able to blow the Shields. If you get killed early from attacking LS characters or just bad luck with draws, it will take much longer to blow the shields. The longer you take, the longer the LS can cause damage. Walkers usually deploys a lot of cards, so it can have a hard time winning if it has to eat several turns of damage or loses a key card. The other weakness is the system. Walkers have to be able to set up in space to drain for free. Your direct damage can be limited by multiple copies of Imperial Atrocity (V6). Since the Re Edit prevents you from getting back Interrupts when you deploy AT-ATs, you no longer have the ability to play Control over and over again. This means the Atrocities stay in play more often, especially against WHAP and Secure Route (V6). Walkers can still be a powerful option for DS but you may have a harder time winning since you have one less Walker Garrison to play. You really need the 8 damage from the Shields to go through or it can take a long time to win. LS has many forms of retrieval, so you have to make sure you are constantly causing damage. You also have to worry about spies like Corran Horn coming down first turn to kill your AT-AT that you have just set up to blow the Shields. Profit will always be Walkers worst match-up because they can pull spy Leia and her matching blaster rifle which makes vehicles lost when hit. This strategy is not as powerful as it used to be when the LS could play Colo Claw Fish and stack a destiny to kill your walker through attrition but it can still be trouble with some lucky draws.\par -----\par Article at DeckTech, November 1st, 2005\par Top 5 Damage-Controlling V-Cards (Dark Side) by Armaedes and Shewski\par \par Another #3, and another strange pick. I limited the text to the 7 side of this objective since it contains the "retrieval" text that made me choose this card. Dark Side retrieval of any sort is very limited, so to me reliable "retrieval" that's immune to Aim High gets my attention. Much like No Escape, this Objective lets you get cards back to hand, which can mean that painful cards like EPP Maul can constantly be cycling out of your Lost Pile and back into play. While limited in deck use, I believe this text helped make Walkers such a powerful deck when it became legal to play. I would estimate that many Walkers decks would be able to get about 3 uses of this text, since many played some cheap walkers that were worth trading for stronger cards. Much like Secure Route (V), the power of this text is limited only by your creativity. Some of my favorite uses are to pull strong Interrupts, Arica, the aforementioned EPP Maul, or some pesky Ice Storms.\par \par ARMAEDES' TAKE:\par Now this is an original choice! The problem with this is that it's (obviously) about as deck-specific as you can get. This works in only ONE dark side deck, and although the immune-to-Aim-High retrieval is nice I would have had a hard time justifying the inclusion of this card on my own list just because it of course will not work in any other deck besides walkers.
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-9)\par This objective provides a specific exception to the rule that your game deck must contain 60 cards, all from the same side of the Force. When playing this objective, your game deck must contain 59 dark side cards (including the objective) and the light side location Hoth: Main Power Generators. When you deploy the Main Power Generators, you must still orient the card such that the blue lightsaber icon is facing the light side player. Lore: "Obi-Wan has taught you well."
Gametext: Cancel All Too Easy, Stunning Leader (where your Jedi participating), Imperial Barrier (targeting your Jedi), or You Are Beaten (except when canceling Uncontrollable Fury). (Immune to Sense.) OR Once per game, if opponent just initiated a battle, you may take the first weapons segment action.
Information: Article at DeckTech, September 19th, 2005\par Top 5 Battle-Aiding V-Cards (Light Side) by Armaedes and Shewski\par \par Last on the list because of how specific it is, but still a solid battling helper due to its ability to cancel just about every battle evasion method dark side can come up with. The trick is that it has to be targeting a Jedi, but frankly most light battling decks are going to be heavy on the Jedi anyway (Mace Windu (V), Qui-Gon Jinn, Obi-Wan Kenobi and possible a Jedi persona of Luke Skywalker). Cancelling battle evasion is obviously a very good thing for a battling deck, but the card doesn't stop there. If your main should survive the battle and are still at the site, and the dark player retaliates, you can use this card to take the first action of the weapons phase, which means you can strike out at one of your opponent's characters before they have a chance to do any tricks with Dr. Evazan or Dark Strike.\par \par SHEWSKI'S TAKE:\par #5?? Aw, man it's my #1. I don't want to steal my own thunder- so read on. I think this was a very good card to come out of the player designed card experiment.\par When you deploy to battle in modern SWCCG, the biggest thing you fear is the re-beat, where your opponent minimizes your offensive power, reinforces on their turn, and then beats you down. Evasion and character removal are two prime ways to slow down a feisty LS player. IMI takes care of it all. I don't think its specificity is a hindrance at all. Barrier will often be saved for your big guns (Jedi). Most battles involve Jedi (Stunning), and YAB will target those aforementioned big guns. Being able to battle on your own terms is very nice. The secondary text is quite nice as well, as Armaedes pointed out. Though protective in nature, it can turn a defensive battle into an offensive one quickly.\par \par ARMAEDES' TAKE:\par I agree that this is a great card, but #1? This is a very deck-specific card, as it won't work in a battling deck that isn't mains, and even in a mains deck it won't help you with EPP Luke. A very nice card no doubt, as it made my own list, but not an auto-play by any means.

Information: ClubsFan, PC forums\par Fri Jul 29, 2005 3:45 pm:\par \par Characters in enclosed vehicles can control sites, because they provide presence (even though they are not present at the site).\par \par So, if you control a marker site with a speeder piloted by a Rebel character, you control that site "with a speeder and a Rebel."\par -----\par Article on DeckTech, August 19th, 2007 '2nd Annual SWCCG Encyclopedia of Decks' by Brandon "Jabba_the_Ruck" Ruck\par http://www.decktech.net/starwarsccg/articles/articles.php?id=6526&view=2\par \par Popular Cards to Look For: Commander Luke (V4), General Rieekan (V4), Romas "Lock� Nevander (V4), T-47 Battle Formation, Frostbite (V4), Maneuvering Flaps (V4) or non V, Echo Base Garrison, any number of speeders that could be non-unique or the named Rogues 1-4, Haven, X-Wings or standard LS Capitals\par \par Idea Behind Objective: A PC created virtual objective that had a very nice run for a while. The whole time you hung out on Hoth, just doing your thing until you won. This objective is very easy to flip with a very solid 7 side. Basically, you would have flipped by just controlling three marker sites with a Rebel and speeder or non-unique trooper. This could be done very easily with Rieekan (V) and Commander Luke (V) both pulling cards that you use to flip. Once flipped, you just would set up each marker site with a speeder and a rebel, because the objective will cause direct damage for each pair. With Frostbite (V), you can retrieve Force if the pairs are matching, like Luke on Rogue 1, Zev on Rogue 2, Wedge on Rogue 3, or Hobbie on Rogue 4. The objective allows you to take ANY card you want into hand from reserve for just 2 force during your Control phase. It also protects from random force loss by reducing any loss that is not a drain at a battleground, your card, or battle damage to just one force. In the old version of this objective all the direct damage was limited to 1 Force a turn. After the Re Edit, you can only reduce direct damage by the number of Hoth locations you occupy, which is still powerful but now has some limits.\par \par How It Can Win: The best things going for this deck are protection under the shields, the ability to 'react' the speeders, high force loss with T-47 Battle Formation (which is now once per game and immune to Sense), always having the right card you need by searching your Reserve during control phase, the limit of opponent's direct damage, and many ways to set up steady retrieval (Frostbite (V4), Uh-Oh(V7), On the Edge, etc). All you have to do is put Luke at the 4th marker, Wedge at the 3rd marker, and just drain, retrieve and wait. If the DS left you alone, you almost always won. In most games, it will all come down to how long you can stay alive on the Hoth system. Since the objective restricts you deploying ANY other battleground locations besides Hoth sites, you have no other options for space unless the DS gives you another system. For this deck to win, it has to stay alive in space so it can afford to deploy new stuff and pay for the retrieval. If you lose control of Hoth early, most dark decks will not give you another system to occupy.\par \par What Changed Since 1st Edition: The Re Edit totally changed how fast this deck sets up. The first change was taking away the Echo Command Center as one of your starting sites. Then Commander Luke (V4) lost the deploy -2 aboard Rogue 1, so it now requires a whole extra turn to flip no matter what. The rest of the objective plays out the same. It can still set up direct damage of up to 3 at each marker site as long as you have a speeder and a Rebel there. Plus you still have the protection of the Shields. Since the deck is no longer as strong as it used to be, some new versions have been built. The most recent version plays like 20 non-unique speeders and sets up a beatdown with Maneuvering Flap (non V). Since the non-uniques are so cheap to set up, the deck can flip as fast as it did before the Re Edit because it doesn't rely on Commander Luke (V4) or General Rieekan (V4). The problem was that it had no way of attacking DS decks that stayed inside at interior sites. If the DS was smart, they drained at the interior sites and never gave the LS an opportunity to beatdown.\par \par Why I SHOULD Play It: Despite the changes from the Re Edit, Speeders can still be a difficult LS deck to beat. The deck does a little bit of everything with direct damage, retrieval, ability to search Reserve deck, plus the built in protection from DS direct damage. The deck still provides the ability to set up on many sites under the shields before the DS can hope to fight. And even though you might see J'Quille (V8) (who deploys through the Shields), Scum is not as popular as it used to be and neither is J'Quille (V8), so the odds of playing against him are much less. You get to play with Ice Storm to make characters missing at your marker sites. The deck can also set up Mechanical Failure against attacking walkers since you can find any card in your Reserve when you need it. When playing Speeders, it is important to include one of the two ways to lower the shields. Either Romas (V4) at the Command Center or Echo Base Trooper Officer (V4) at a non-shielded marker site, usually 4th Marker. Speeders is still a good match-up for SYCFA Fear since they don't play any ground, you can easily occupy enough Hoth locations to absorb the Fear damage. The key again is staying alive in space. Since you can retrieve Force during your control phase, the best way to stay alive in space is with Alternatives to Fighting from A New Hope. This card lets you pay 3 Force to cancel ANY just initiated Starship battle. So if they wasted their grabber, you can easily retrieve it after the opponent's battle phase to play over and over again.\par \par Why NOT to Play It: The Re Edit really took away the speed of this deck. The DS can set up very fast these days, so you can't afford that extra turn it takes to flip with the matching speeders. The matching speeder version was much stronger than the non-unique version since you had immunity to attrition with Echo Base Garrsion as well as retrieval with Frostbite (V4). The biggest hit was the T-47 Battle Formation being made Out of Play. The LS Hoth objective was strong because it could set up fast and be ready to play both T-47 before the DS could stop them. Since you lost a whole turn of big drain, the deck can take that much longer to defeat the opponent. The other problems with the deck still exist. J'Quille (V8) can deploy straight through the shields to ANY of your sites. So you can get caught in a beatdown if you don't have a Houjix. The DS can still put out their own 5th Marker (Ice Plains) which removes the 4th Marker as your second battleground location. That leaves the system as your only battleground unless you are able to lower the shields. The DS can easily play the Come Here You Big Coward shield to prevent any drains or retrieval while the 'Hoth Shield Rules' are in effect. You can only do damage while the shields are down, which leaves all your sites open for the DS to deploy straight through. The deck still has problems with DS space based decks that set up and control the Hoth system from the very beginning of the game. Since it takes you longer to flip, you are not able to send forces to the system as quickly while the DS uses 3 to 4 turns to pile up as many ships as they want. Speeders will always fear Sunsdown Combo being played to reduce all the speeders power and forfeit to ZERO. Most Speeders deck have to play 2x Houjix to stand a chance should this unlikely event occur.

Lore: "Your tauntaun'll freeze before you reach the first marker."
Gametext: Take Cold Feet, He Hasn't Come Back Yet, or Ice Storm into hand from Reserve Deck; reshuffle. OR Cancel Dodge. OR Cancel opponent's 'react' away from battle. OR Cancel opponent's attempt to randomly remove one or more cards from your hand (except with Grimtaash).
Information: Article at DeckTech, September 19th, 2005\par Top 5 Battle-Aiding V-Cards (Dark Side) by Armaedes and Shewski\par \par It should be obvious why Stop Motion (V) is a good card for a battling deck - it stops your opponent from moving away from battles. In addition to cancelling Dodge, it can also cancel the 'react' of the annoying Arcona. The card is also a used high destiny interrupt that has some nice recycling gametext so that if you don't need it at the time or if you have multiples in your hand, it can be easily put back into your reserve deck. Finally, the last line of text also helps with your battling as it prevents your opponent from removing key cards from your hand right before you administer the beatings, ensuring that once you get your battling combo in your hand it will stay there, provided you stay below 13 cards in hand.\par \par SHEWSKI'S TAKE:\par Good call. Much like IMI, this card helps make sure that your battles go through. This was very big when LSC had teeth and evasion like Dodge was in vogue. It's a neat idea, but in modern SWCCG I can't think of prominent reacting away from battles for the LS other than Hyper Escape, which Firepower deals with.
Pulls: Cold Feet\par Cold Feet (V11)\par He Hasn't Come Back Yet\par Ice Storm
IsPulled: Tauntaun Skull
Cancels: Dodge\par One 'react' away from battle.\par Opponent's attempt to randomly remove one or more cards from your hand (except with Grimtaash)

CardName: It Is The Future You See (V2)
Gametext: If you deployed only 1 location (unless it is [Coruscant], [Reflections III], or [Special Edition]), play instead of a Starting Interrupt. Deploy Battle Plan, Do, Or Do Not, and an [Immune to Alter] Effect. Revolution, insert cards, and your [Maintenance] and [Permanent Weapon] cards are lost. You go first. Choose one: \par \b Jedi:\b0  Deploy on table. At start of your turn, turn all cards here face up. During your turn, may use 1 Force for each card stacked here to stack a card from hand face up here. Instead of using X Force, may turn X cards here face down.\par\b Agent of Evil:\b0  Take Luke and a site into hand from Reserve Deck; reshuffle. Deploy on opponent's side of table; their total battle and duel destiny is +2.
Information: Player Created Card\par Original concept by Chuck Sonnenburg, PC Volunteer Award 2005\par -----\par Article on DeckTech, August 19th, 2007 '2nd Annual SWCCG Encyclopedia of Decks' by Brandon "Jabba_the_Ruck" Ruck\par http://www.decktech.net/starwarsccg/articles/articles.php?id=6526&view=2\par \par Starting Locations: ANY One (NON-Coruscant or Special Edition) location\par \par Popular Cards to Look For: MWYHL, Luke (V11), Tatooine: Slave Quarters, Twixes, Revolution\par \par Idea Behind Design: It Is The Future You See (V12) has completely opened up a new deck design for LS by creating a new way for the LS to go first over starting the Yavin 4: Throne Room. Just like TRMs, you only get one location to start the game. And it can't be a Coruscant or Special Edition location. This is probably because they didn't want Hidden Base getting to go first and they didn't want you to be able to start the Coruscant: Jedi Council Chamber since that would have been the most popular choice. The Epic Event is started in place of a Starting Interrupt. From there, it says you are required to start Battle Plain and Do or Do Not plus ANY third Effect that is immune to Alter. Of course all players should be playing the combo versions of both Battle Plain and Do or Do not. The card goes on to say that no 'insert' cards may be played. So even though you lose the ability to start two Effects of any kind, you start the game with 3 shields already in play. From there you have yet another decision to make, whether or not to be a Jedi or An Agent of Evil. By choosing Jedi, you keep the Epic Event on your side and for the rest of the game may stack cards from hand on top of the Epic Event by paying X Force where X is the number of cards stacked. You may then use the stacked cards in place of Force by turning them over. At the beginning of your turn, they turn back over to be used again. What this does is provide you constant Force to use all game. So you are no longer affected by DS cards that can manipulate your Force pile and attempt to leave you weak to First Strike beatdowns. Should you decide to choose the Agent of Evil route, you may immediately take any Luke and any 1 site into hand. The Epic Event then deploys on opponents side of table adding +3 to the DS total battle and duel destinies. With so many different options for both Jedi and Agent of Evil strategies, IITFYS (V12) has no end to the possible deck designs.\par \par How It Can Win: This card has only been out a few months and in that time there have been a few very solid options for this deck. The main build is of course MWYHL since this Epic Event used to be a Jedi Test. You can now play a training MWYHL and go first, so you start training before the DS even has a turn. The Epic Event also provides you extra Force for setting up faster. This new card can be very powerful with Dagobah since you can play 2x Stone Pile to remove two random cards from opponents hand. There are currently three ways you can play through Dagobah. You can do MWYHL and do training from just 1 all the way to 6 and basically play a regular MWYHL strategy with a different start since you can't start the same 3 Effects. If you don't want to train, you can just use the MWYHL set up for activation and play any other strategy. Some choose to start just Dagobah without the objective so your characters can retrieve on Dagobah. You lose the protection from SAC and the auto pulling of SOS, Yoda, and Daughter, but gain more options for setting up on Dagobah like the old days. The third idea is to just start Yoda's Hut and play the deck like TRMs with just twix sites. Since you can pull any Luke and any site with Agents of Evil, the most popular choice has been Luke (V11) and Beggar's Canyon. Because you can go first, you are able to set up the Luke (V11) on your first turn every game. His text works like Hidden Base saying while he pilots alone at a Beggar's Canyon, the DS must pay 1 Force to draw a card or retrieve a Force. The most common strategy with this is to start Rycar (V2) and set up Meditation and I'm With You Too (V9). The Meditation gives you another battle destiny, while IWYT (V9) says you can lose 3 Force to cancel a battle destiny. There is no limit to how many destinies you can cancel per turn, so the DS will never be able to kill Luke with attrition. If you combine this with MWYHL and training, you will be retrieving the 3 Force you lost with each completed Jedi Test. If you don't want to worry about training, you can start ANY Tatooine site to be adjacent to the Canyon. If you give Luke a Wrist Comlink with Rycar Ryjerd(V2), the characters set up on the adjacent site may move as a React to any battles at the Canyon. The most popular site for this strategy is the Slave Quarters since it is a twix site that can pull Shmi Skywalker once per game. She can pull Threepio, With Parts Showing, so you would have his text going from turn 1 as well. Combine this deck with Revolution on the DS locations for more Force Choke.\par \par What Changed Since 1st Edition: This is another deck that didn't exist the first time around. Moving on.\par \par Why I SHOULD Play It: Currently, this is by far the freshest idea to hit SWCCG in YEARS. For the first time ever, the LS have another option for going first in the game. The odds of playing a game where the LS goes first is not higher than it was before. Going first can have a HUGE affect on the out come of the game. Your stuff gets in play before your opponent. You will drain first on average before the DS when you go first since they have to choose rather to continue setting up their deck's initial strategy or stopping yours. The LS is all about running away and reacting to the stronger more powerful DS. So they can play the game differently going second versus a DS deck that goes second. TRMs has been such a powerful option for the majority of the game because of the ability to go first in the game. SO, we now have a card that has created a completely new way to go first. You now have SOOOO many options. Even though the DS is stronger right now, this new Epic Event has just started to become a new idea. There is no telling what new deck is still waiting to become a top tier option for LS. Because this is the newest option, you have more reason to try this strategy out than any other. The surprise factor is the easiest way to beat a great player because they don't know exactly what your deck is doing. They might lose a card to a drain that could have made a difference simply because they didn't know what the deck does. For now, the only strategy I have has been listed but please feel free to create some new ideas combine strategies from other decks. It is possible this new idea will become the new TRMs.\par \par Why NOT to Play It: The main reason not to play this deck is because it is somewhat unproven. If you are a player that requires experience with a specific strategy in order to make it work, then you might not be ready for this. The LS doesn't have as many options for decks that can constantly defeat everything. This deck does lose the ability to start two specific Effects, which can be a problem when you need the third Effect for a counter card like Scrambled Transmission (V5), Civil Disorder (V6), etc. It is way too soon to say tell which DS decks give this strategy trouble. From my own experience, SYCFA Fear continues to be its worst match-up since you almost never play with Alter having to start Do or Do Not. And most decks that have been built with this Epic Event are not based around space, so you will have a hard time dealing with all those Destroyers. I am sure as time goes on that this Epic Event will open up many new powerful strategies for LS. For now, it might be a good idea to play around with some ideas before going to a major tournament.
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, B-9)\par The phrase "Instead of using X Force, may turn X cards here face down" means that whenever you need to use Force, rather than placing a card from your Force Pile onto your Used Pile, you may instead turn one of this Epic Event's cards face down. You may pay some or all of the Force cost in this manner. You may use this ability even if your Force pile is empty. This Epic Event cannot be used if you've deployed more than one location, even a location that says it does not count towards calculating Epic Events.

Information: TIE/lns are forfeit +2 at same location as Vengeance.
IsPulled: Commander Brandei\par Deflector Shield Generators (V4)\par I'm Sorry (V12)\par Short Range Fighters & Watch Your Back!
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, D-2)\par Characters, vehicles, and starships can be heroic (whether by their own game text or have it provided). Whenever a heroic card is targeted by a weapon, add 1 to the total weapon destiny. Also, in a battle where there's a heroic card, non-heroic cards cannot be targeted by weapons unless all heroic cards are hit, not participating in battle, or cannot be targeted by that weapon. \par For example, if light has a heroic character (Chewie) in a battle, then any dark side weapons that can target him can only be fired at him, but if they don't (such as targeting only a vehicle, or a non-Rebel character, or a Jedi, etc.) they wouldn't have to, if he was excluded from battle they wouldn't have to, if he left the table they wouldn't have to, if he was inside an enclosed vehicle (where he can't be targeted) they wouldn't have to, or if he was finally hit they wouldn't have to. Light would be able to target whomever they wanted because you can't target your own cards with weapons.
IsCanceledBy: Heroic and immunity to attrition canceled by Precise Hit (V).

CardName: Through The Force Things You Will See (V2)
Lore: One training exercise for a Jedi's apprentice is to invert one's view to see things from a different perspective. "The future, the past. Old friends long gone."
Gametext: Once per game, choose: if you are about to recirculate at the end of your turn, and you have fewer cards in Used Pile than Force Pile, place your Used Pile under your Force Pile instead. OR Place the top card of your Used Pile on top of your Force Pile.
Rules: (AR 1.7.1, F-1)\par Out Of Play Interrupts are identified by their interrupt icon in the upper-left corner of their card, and "Out Of Play Interrupt" in their subtype box. Out Of Play interrupts (or interrupts with an Out Of Play function) are played under normal interrupt rules. Once resolved, they are placed out of play. Once played as an Out Of Play Interrupt, no card of the same title may be played again as an Out Of Play Interrupt (though if it can be played as a Used or Lost Interrupt, it may still be played using its Used or Lost function).
